docs.lead_paragraph: Much of the TV commentariat declared Wednesday that President Obama's prime-time address to Congress was his last best effort to pursue his goal of overhauling health care. But some commentators on the Fox News Channel never gave him much hope in the first place.

headline.main: The Speech Through the Lens of Fox News

docs.abstract: For some Fox News commentators, President Obama didn't have much hope of making his case.
docs.snippet: For some Fox News commentators, President Obama didn't have much hope of making his case.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Times's Kevin Sack has traveled the country, chronicling the stake holders in health care overhaul. We check back in for their reaction to the president's speech.
docs.snippet: The Times's Kevin Sack has traveled the country, chronicling the stake holders in health care overhaul. We check back in for their reaction to the president's speech.

docs.lead_paragraph: During the August Congressional recess, Kevin Sack, a national correspondent for The New York Times, traveled from South Florida to Washington State to sample opinion about health care overhaul from a variety of stakeholders, among them elderly Americans, insurance company workers and medical students. On Wednesday night, The Times asked some of those he had encountered for their views on President Obama's speech to a joint session of Congress. Here's what people had to say. Check back for more as they come in.
docs.abstract: The Times's Kevin Sack has traveled the country, chronicling the stake holders in health care overhaul. We check back in for their reaction to the president's speech.
docs.snippet: The Times's Kevin Sack has traveled the country, chronicling the stake holders in health care overhaul. We check back in for their reaction to the president's speech.

docs.lead_paragraph: We asked a few experts on health care delivery and policy to share their first reactions to President's Obama's speech this evening. Here are their thoughts.

headline.main: Reactions to the Speech: A Health Care Roundtable

docs.abstract: Experts in health care delivery and policy offer their reactions to Obama's speech.
docs.snippet: Experts in health care delivery and policy offer their reactions to Obama's speech.

docs.lead_paragraph: Glenn Loury of Brown University and Virginia Postrel of Dynamist.com discuss health care quality vs. costs.

headline.sub: Is low cost, high quality health care possible?

docs.snippet: Glenn Loury of Brown University and Virginia Postrel of Dynamist.com discuss health care quality vs. costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: David M. Herszenhorn, on Capitol Hill, and Katharine Q. Seelye, in New York, live blogged the president's speech and reaction tonight. President Obama laid out themes of "security and stability" in an effort to reassure Americans about his health care plans. Advance text of the speech.
docs.abstract: Stay with us for the president's speech.
docs.snippet: Stay with us for the president's speech.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

docs.lead_paragraph: Tonight, President Obama will give a much-awaited speech laying out the case for health care reform. Almost exactly 16 years ago, President Bill Clinton did the exact same thing.
docs.abstract: President Obama's speech tonight laying out the case for health care reform will echo almost exactly 16 years ago, when Bill Clinton did the exact same thing, and with language that could be used today.
docs.snippet: President Obama's speech tonight laying out the case for health care reform will echo almost exactly 16 years ago, when Bill Clinton did the exact same thing, and with language that could be used today.

docs.lead_paragraph: When President Obama addresses a joint session of Congress on health care Wednesday night, his audience in the House chamber will include the widow of the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, who was the Senate's strongest advocate of health reform until his death of brain cancer last month.

headline.main: On the President's Guest List Tonight

docs.abstract: Senator Kennedy's widow is among those appearing as a guest of the Obamas.
docs.snippet: Senator Kennedy's widow is among those appearing as a guest of the Obamas.

docs.lead_paragraph: Max Baucus, it seems, is finally ready.

headline.main: Republicans or Not, Mr. Baucus Is Ready

docs.abstract: Max Baucus is ready to press ahead -- Republicans or not.
docs.snippet: Max Baucus is ready to press ahead -- Republicans or not.

docs.lead_paragraph: "Security and stability" - with or without a "public option." That will be the essence of President Obama's message in his health care speech to a joint session of Congress, a senior administration official said Wednesday afternoon.

headline.main: Obama Will Emphasize Security, Not Public Option, in Speech

docs.abstract: In his speech, the president will support a public, government-run insurance option, but will not insist on it.
docs.snippet: In his speech, the president will support a public, government-run insurance option, but will not insist on it.
